newsitem.title: USA: Bristol markets Zerit AIDS drug for children.
newsitem.headline: Bristol markets Zerit AIDS drug for children.

text.p: Bristol-Myers Squibb Thursday unveiled a new oral formulation of its ZERIT drug, for the treatment of infants and children infected with the human immunodeficiency virus, which causes AIDS.
ZERIT, also called "stavudine, d4T" has been available for adults in the U.S. since June 1994, in Europe since May 1996, and in several other countries worldwide, the company said.
Bristol-Myers said that in a recently completed AIDS Clinical Trials Group Study, children receiving ZERIT had fewer side effects than those taking AZT, an AIDS drug made by Glaxo Wellcome Plc.

"Children receiving stavudine experienced better weight gain, and their absolute CD4+ lymphocyte counts were better maintained than children taking AZT," said Mark Kline of Baylor College of Medicine in Houston.
"Patients in the d4T group encountered significantly fewer episodes of low white blood cell counts compared to the AZT group," he said.

A number of clinical trials are underway to determine the safety and efficacy of ZERIT in combination with other HIV/AIDS treatments, including nucleoside analogues and protease inhibitors, the company said.
